text: The applicant complained that the length of the maintenance payment proceedings had been incompatible with the “reasonable time” principle as provided in Article 6 § 1 of the Convention, which reads as follows:
label: conclusion

text: The Court notes that this complaint is not manifestly ill-founded within the meaning of Article 35 § 3 of the Convention.
label: premise

text: It further notes that it is not inadmissible on any other grounds.
label: premise

text: It must therefore be declared admissible.
label: conclusion

text: (see, among many other authorities, Frydlender v. France [GC], no. 30979/96, § 43, ECHR 2000-VII).
label: premise

text: The Court reiterates that the reasonableness of the length of proceedings must be assessed in the light of the circumstances of the case and with reference to the criteria established by its case-law, particularly the complexity of the case, the conduct of the applicant and of the relevant authorities and what was at stake for the applicant in the dispute
label: conclusion
events: ['court reiterate ', 'reasonableness must be assess light', ' establish law']

text: The Court reiterates that the reasonableness of the length of proceedings must be assessed in the light of the circumstances of the case and with reference to the criteria established by its case-law, particularly the complexity of the case, the conduct of the applicant and of the relevant authorities and what was at stake for the applicant in the dispute
label: premise
events: ['court reiterate ', 'reasonableness must be assess light', ' establish law']

text: The Court considers that the present proceedings can clearly be distinguished from the custody proceedings, as they concerned merely the fixing of maintenance payments and were not particularly complex.
label: premise
events: ['company sider ', 'proceeding can be distinguish proceeding', 'company cerne fixing']

label: premise
events: [' regard duct', 'court have hold ', 'applicant can be not blame ']

text: However, an applicant's behaviour constitutes an objective fact which cannot be attributed to the respondent State and which must be taken into account for the purpose of determining whether or not the reasonable time referred to in Article 6 § 1 has been exceeded

text: In the present case, the Court acknowledges that the applicant had filed numerous requests, complaints and motions and had repeatedly failed to obey the authorities' summons.
label: premise
events: ['court acknowledge ', 'applicant have file request', 'applicant have fail ', ' to obey summon']

text: Although such conduct contributed to prolonging the proceedings, it is not in itself sufficient to explain the length of the extensive proceedings.

text: On the other hand, the Court notes that there are substantial delays attributable to the authorities.
label: premise

text: In particular, in the first set of proceedings, there is a period of inactivity of more than two years (from 3 January 1990 to 10 February 1992) while the case was pending before the Vienna Juvenile Court, and a further one of six years (from 13 May 1992 to 20 May 1998) before that court took a new decision after the first one had been quashed on appeal.
label: premise
events: ['there be period', ' pende court', 'rt take decision', 'one have be quash appeal']

text: The Court cannot find that the Government has given sufficient explanation for these delays that occurred.
label: premise
events: ['court can not find ', 'government have give explanation', 'that occur ']

text: In the second set of proceedings, there is a period of inactivity of some three years (from 4 September 1990 to 10 August 1993), while the case was pending before the Vienna Juvenile Court, and a further such period of three years and seven months (from 5 January 1995 to 5 August 1998) before that court took a new decision after the first one had been quashed on appeal.
label: premise
events: ['there be period', ' pende court', 'rt take decision', 'one have be quash appeal']

text: The Court therefore finds that the overall length of the proceedings cannot be regarded as “reasonable”. Accordingly, there has been a violation of Article 6 § 1 of the Convention.
label: conclusion
